root.TEXT:
Record date: 2061-01-31
EDVISIT^32707420^GIPSON, ALEXANDER^01/31/61^VELASQUEZ, WALTER
This patient was seen by myself and Dr. Hardin on 01/31/2061. I
confirm I interviewed and examined the patient, reviewed the
resident's documentation, and discussed the plan of care with the
patient.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: This is a 73-year-old gentleman who
has a history of CAD status post stent in 2060, who developed
acute chest discomfort, pressure like, diaphoresis, and weakness,
while he was working as a chiropractor. He says although this
was quite significant, it was not like his prior MI discomfort.
He denies any radiation to his back or his arm. He denies any
jaw pain. He denies any fever, chills, or sweats. He denies any
vomiting. He denies any headache or neck pain. He denies any
bowel or bladder changes and no lower extremity edema. He is
taking his medicines. He also took an aspirin, did get some
nitroglycerin.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Diabetes, hypertension,
hypercholesterolemia, and CAD.
MEDICATIONS: Cozaar, aspirin, Altace, metformin, and Toprol.
ALLERGIES: He has no known drug allergies.
SOCIAL HISTORY: He is a past smoker, not a drinker or drug user.
He lives with his family.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: As noted in the HPI, otherwise negative.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: He is in no acute distress at rest. He
says his chest pain is essentially gone on oxygen. Vital signs
are as noted. Head, eyes, ears, nose, and throat: Normocephalic
and atraumatic. Pupils are equal and reactive to light.
Extraocular motions are intact. Oropharynx is unremarkable.
Neck is supple. There is no jugular venous distention. Chest is
clear to auscultation. Heart is regular rate and rhythm. His
abdomen is soft and nontender. There is no hepatosplenomegaly.
There are no masses. His skin is warm and dry. There is no
lower extremity edema. He has equal pulses. His neuro exam is
alert and oriented to person, place, and time. His cranial
nerves are intact. He is grossly nonfocal.
LABORATORY DATA: He has a white count of 8, hematocrit of 46,
and platelet count of 200,000. His SMA-7 is unremarkable. CK-MB
and troponin are flat and INR is 1. His EKG shows less than 1 mm
ST depressions in V2, without any reciprocal or other changes.
ASSESSMENT: The patient with a history of CAD with concerning
symptoms. He did have a fight earlier in the day, although was
not under significant stress at the time of this event. Given
his prior CAD history, the patient was given Lopressor. Decision
was made to admit him for rule out acute coronary syndrome. The
patient was admitted in stable condition. The patient had
already got an aspirin and the patient remained in stable
condition until he was admitted.
DIAGNOSIS: Rule out acute coronary syndrome.
______________________________
VELASQUEZ, WALTER M.D.
D: 01/31/61
T: 02/01/61
Dictated By: VELASQUEZ, WALTER
eScription document:9-1137686 BFFocus
